Identity is not something YOU determine for YOURSELF. It's not a "right". You can control many things, from your actions to your thoughts (putting aside discussions of free will), and can certainly have ideas about who you are, but your identity is not something you get to just dictate to everyone all by yourself. Your identity is something that, by and large, others ascribe to you in addition to your choices in how you conduct yourself. You can certainly insist that you think you're an elf, or the reincarnation of Jesus, or some new gender term, but that doesn't mean you have the "right" to legislate that your "identity" be "respected". Other people will decide for themselves whether you are respectable on terms outside your control. Other people will generate their own ideas of who you and ascribe you identity based upon the way you act and present yourself. You have zero control over this, because you don't have this "fundamental right" to "self-determinate your own identity" unless you're saying that identity is entirely subjective and you can somehow force people to abide by what you dictate.
What's to stop me from lying and cheating my way through life and then insisting to everyone I meet "Nah I'm an honest man because *I* feel like an honest man!"? If identity is totally subjective and people are obligated to respect it, why can't I proclaim myself as disabled because I "feel like I'm disabled" and get benefits for it? You're violating my fundamental rights, apparently!
Now you can go around saying "I am X" all you like. You can dress how you like. You can behave how you like (within reason). That's fine. Go nuts. I don't have to automatically hold any kind of respect for you simply because you're "genderfluid", nor do I *have* to use whatever made up pronouns you demand people use, and nor do I have to be tolerant of everything you do or say simply because you think that your feelings dictate reality for others.

I'm mainly talking about the latency and hit box issues coupled with the poor balancing when I talk about what is broken. It's one thing to have lag. It's another to systematically have latency and hit box issues even when offline. Straight swords should not have longer reach and better stun than great swords, and the fact that they have is representative of the above issues.
As far as artificial difficulty, I don't think it's inherently bad. Sometimes you need to let a boss "cheat" as a way of showing how powerful he is supposed to be. Take Baldur's Gate 2. The final boss in that game is a powerful magic user, so powerful that the game gives in universe justification for him being able to ignore and bend the usually strict game mechanics and make him immune to your usual anti magic tactics. The problem with dark souls is it doesn't so much have this kind of artificial difficulty so much as it has "throw a chain axe through two walls to insta kill you" or "grapple you even though he clearly missed you". That's just my impression. I still like dark souls, I just don't think its issues were ever sorted out.

Still don't get why people praise this game endlessly. It's broken, filled with massive latency and balance issues, artificial difficulty, and repetitive mechanics. I played all three dark souls and love the atmosphere and "spirit" of the game. But during that entire series, nothing was ever fixed because the moment you complain you're beset by the hordes of people whose main life achievement is beating this "hard game". If it were any other game, it would be vilified for the glaring issues it has. It's amazing to me.

I've felt like this for awhile. I always made the analogy of a burning candle.The fire is our consciousness, the light our perception. Most assume there is something special about us because we can perceive, some even take it so far as to say that reality is predicated on our perception. But the fire on a candle is not special because it casts light. It is simply an amalgam of physical laws and interacting components that sum up to the flame that illuminates-not magically, but because of the way it is composed. Such is our consciousness too; an amalgam of smaller parts and universal laws that sums up to a form of interaction with the outer Universe. Like the flame, we "cast light" in the form of our perception, with our mistake being we assume this is some special quality, perhaps even what makes things exist. But if we snuff out a candle it has no effect on anything, and the universe does not stop existing simply because there is now no light to illuminate it. The same is true of our self; just a flame. Pretty, impressive, but simply a trick on itself, where all of it's components unite to form the whole of our flame and that flame insists that the universe is predicated upon the light it casts, simply because the flame can never know that what lies in the dark will exist after it no longer exists to cast light upon it.
